questions.title: I
questions.article:
Bacteria reproduce by a process in which a single cell divides into two cells. The average time required for bacteria to divide and their population to double is called the generation time. Table 1 presents the generation time for a variety of bacteria at a given temperature.

Bacterial population growth occurs in a series of distinct steps referred to as a bacterial growth curve. It consists of 4 phases, which reflect changes in the cells' environment and metabolism over time. See Figure 1.
questions.question: 1. On the basis of the data presented in Table 1, if Streptococcus lactis was placed in a test tube containing growth medium at 37℃, one would predict its generation time to most likely be:

choices.B: between 10 and 15 min.

questions.title: I
questions.article:

questions.question: 2. The bacterial population increases most rapidly during which of the following phases?

choices.B: Log phase

questions.question: 3. Based on the data presented in Table 1, which of the following bacteria growing in glucose broth took the longest time to double its population?

choices.B: Staphylococcus aureus

questions.title: I
questions.article:

questions.question: 4. Samples of growth medium containing milk were inoculated with the microorganisms depicted in Table 1 and put in an environmental chamber at 37°C. Which of the following bacteria would take closest to 1 hour to double its population?

choices.B: Mycobacterium tuberculosis

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Bacteria reproduce by a process in which a single cell divides into two cells. The average time required for bacteria to divide and their population to double is called the generation time. Table 1 presents the generation time for a variety of bacteria at a given temperature.

Bacterial population growth occurs in a series of distinct steps referred to as a bacterial growth curve. It consists of 4 phases, which reflect changes in the cells' environment and metabolism over time. See Figure 1.
questions.question: 5. Which of the following hypotheses about bacterial populations is supported by the data presented in Figure 1 ?

choices.A: Bacteria populations change at a constant rate throughout all the growth phases.
choices.B: Bacteria begin to increase immediately after transfer to a new growth medium.
choices.C: Bacteria begin to decrease immediately after transfer to a new growth medium.
choices.D: Bacteria require a period of adjustment before they begin to reproduce in a new growth medium.

questions.title: II
questions.article:
Scientists noted an increase in plant growth in a lake. Increased growth of lake weeds and algae is usually the result of an increased input of nutrients, especially phosphates and nitrates. Nitrates are easily carried by water moving through the soil (groundwater) or streams. Phosphates can attach to soil or stream sediment particles.To determine the primary source of nutrients entering the lake, scientists conducted the following experiments.

Experiment 1
Scientists deduced that one source of phosphates and nitrates was seepage from wastewater systems buried in the soil near houses adjacent to the lake. Sampling wells were placed in locations where samples of groundwater, flowing from houses toward the lake, could be obtained daily. The results are presented in Table 1.



Experiment 2
Scientists suspected that another source of nutrients where fertilizers was the runoff from nearby farm lands were applied.Water and suspended-sediment samples were obtained from two streams that flowed into the lake.These streams intercept surface runoff from the farm lands during rainfall and snowmelt.The results are depicted in Table 2.
questions.question: 6. How do the designs of Experiments 1 and 2 differ in terms of the sampling procedure?

choices.A: In Experiment 1, sampling was performed daily, whereas in Experiment 2, sampling was performed weekly.
choices.B: In Experiment 1, groundwater was sampled, whereas in Experiment 2, stream water was sampled.
choices.C: In Experiment 1, suspended sediment concentration was sampled, whereas in Experiment 2, suspended sediment concentration was not sampled.
choices.D: In Experiment 1, only nitrate concentration was sampled, whereas in Experiment 2, only phosphate concentration was sampled.

Experiment 2

questions.question: 7. In order to obtain more information about the relationship between phosphates, nitrates, and plant growth, which of the following procedures should be performed next?

choices.A: Studying how the lake weeds grow in water maintained at different temperatures
choices.B: Growing algae in water samples containing several different phosphate and nitrate concentrations
choices.C: Adding large amounts of phosphates and nitrates to the soil of House 1
choices.D: Decreasing the amount of irrigation used by local farmers

questions.question: 8. Scientists suspected that fertilizers applied to farm lands also contaminated groundwater, which in turn increased nutrient input into the lake. In order to best test this hypothesis, which of the following should the scientists do next?

choices.A: Sample water from three different streams
choices.B: Measure the increase in algae and plant growth in the lake
choices.C: Increase the amount of fertilizer applied to nearby farm lands
choices.D: Vary the amount of fertilizer applied to nearby farm lands and sample groundwater flowing toward the lake in these fields

questions.question: 9. What was the scientists' hypothesis concerning lake plant growth in Experiment 1 ?

choices.A: Wastewater from houses increases lake plant growth.
choices.B: Runoff from farm lands decreases lake plant growth.
choices.C: Rain falling in the vicinity of the houses and lake decreases lake plant growth.
choices.D: Lake sediments release nitrates and phosphates into areas where plants are least abundant.

questions.question: 10. Given the results of Experiments 1 and 2, all of the following measures would reduce the input of phosphorus and nitrogen into the lake EXCEPT:

choices.A: increasing the number of houses surrounding the lake.
choices.B: limiting surface runoff and erosion on upstream farm lands.
choices.C: limiting fertilizer application on upstream farm lands.
choices.D: installing pipes to carry wastewater to a central treatment facility.

questions.question: 11. As phosphates move farther from their source, they are more likely to be adsorbed by the soil (removed from the water). Which of the following would most likely be the approximate phosphate concentration for House 1 on May 3 if the sampling well were closer to the wastewater system of the house?

choices.B: 7.0 mg/L

questions.title: III
questions.article:
Motor vehicle exhaust is a significant source of several air pollutants, including the nitrogen oxides, NO2 and NO. Scientists performed two experiments to investigate the levels and behavior of these pollutants and naturally occurring gases in the atmosphere near busy roadways.

Experiment 1
Scientists studied how NO2, levels vary with vehicle use. They measured NO2 levels hourly for a 24-hour period, 10 meters (m) downwind from six roadways. Each roadway had a combination of a different speed limit and vehicle usage (approximate number of vehicles per day). An average NO2 value for each roadway was calculated in parts per billion (ppb). The results are in Table 1.



Experiment 2
Next, levels of NO2 and NO were measured at 0, and 100 m downwind from the 100 km/hr roadway which averaged 30,000 vehicles per day. The level of NO2 decreased from 30 ppb at 0 m to 17 ppb at 100 m. The level of NO decreased from 150 ppb at 0 m to 42 ppb at 100 m.
(Note: The levels of NO2 and NO that would be found far from pollution sources are 15 ppb and 35 ppb, respectively.)


Experiment 3
Ozone (O3) is a naturally occurring gas in the atmosphere. Levels of ozone, in parts per million (ppm) were taken at various distances downwind from the 100 km/hr roadway which averaged 30,000 vehicles per day. The results are in Table 2.
(Note:The naturally occurring ozone concentration is 0.12 ppm.)
questions.question: 12. Which of the following factors was varied in Experiment 3 ?

choices.B: Background level of ozone

questions.question: 13. According to the experimental results, one way to reduce levels of NO2 in an area would be to:

choices.A: reduce the levels of naturally occurring ozone near roadways.
choices.B: lower speed limits on the roadways.
choices.C: raise speed limits on the roadways.
choices.D: require installation of ozone filters in motor vehicle exhaust systems.

questions.question: 14. According to the experimental results, if one compared ozone levels near a major highway to those in a remote wilderness location, ozone levels:

choices.A: near the highway would be higher than at the wilderness location.
choices.B: near the highway would be lower than at the wilderness location.
choices.C: near the highway would be the same as those in the wilderness location.
choices.D: would be detectable only near the highway.

questions.question: 15. Carbon monoxide (CO) is another pollutant associated with motor vehicle exhaust. If carbon monoxide behaves like the nitrogen oxides in the experiments, one would expect that carbon monoxide levels:

choices.B: would stay the same over time.
choices.C: are higher near roadways than farther away from them.
choices.D: are lower near roadways than farther away from them.

questions.question: 16. According to the results of the experiments, as distance from the roadway increases:

choices.A: NO2 and ozone levels both increase.
choices.B: NO2 levels increase and ozone levels decrease.
choices.C: NO2 levels increase and ozone levels stay the same.
choices.D: NO2 levels decrease and ozone levels increase.

questions.question: 17. A certain roadway has a speed limit of 100 km/hr and an average vehicle usage of 100,000 vehicles per day. One would predict that 10 m downwind from this roadway NO2 levels are:

choices.B: between 8 and 13 ppb.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
The following experiments were done to study factors that affect the precession of a top. Precession is the revolution of a top around an imaginary line perpendicular to the surface at the point of contact (see Figure 1).



Experiment 1
An electric motor was attached to a top and used to give the top a known spin rate or number of revolutions per minute (rpm). Once the desired spin rate was achieved, the motor was removed and the number of precessions per minute was counted. The process was repeated using different spin rates. The results are recorded in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The distance from the surface to the top's center of gravity (r) was varied by changing the length of the light-weight stem on the top from Experiment 1. The electric motor was used to generate the same spin rate in each trial. The measured precession rate is given in Table 2.


Experiment 3
A scientist took the top from Experiment 1 to the Moon. It was found that for a given spin rate and stem length, the precession rate was approximately one-sixth that on Earth. For example, a precession rate of 12 rpm on Earth would be approximately 2 rpm on the Moon.
questions.question: 18. Based on the results of Experiment 2, one can conclude that the precession rate of a top increases as the stem:

choices.B: increases in length.

questions.article:

questions.question: 19. Which of the following graphs best represents the with increasing spin rate as change in precession rate shown in Experiment 1 ?

choices.A: several different planets with varying gravities.
choices.B: one other planet with the same gravity as Earth.

questions.question: 21. If the spin rate used in Experiment 2 was 500 rpm, what is most likely the value of r in Experiment 1 ?

choices.B: 4 inches

questions.question: 22. If the techniques of Experiment 1 had not been perfected first, how would this have affected Experiment 2 ?

choices.A: The mass of the top would have been a factor.
choices.B: The spin rate might not have been the same in each trial.
choices.C: The top's mass may have redistributed itself.
choices.D: The top's shape may have changed.

questions.question: 23. How would one best investigate the effect of a top's mass on the precession rate if the spin rate is constant?

choices.B: Use tops that are the same size, have the same shape, and are made from different metals
choices.C: Try different tops and test them on both the Earth and Moon
choices.D: Try tops with equal mass but stems of different lengths

questions.title: V
questions.article:
Lightning is a visible electrical emission that often occurs in a cloud that has positive charges at the top and negative charges at the base (bottom). Two theories attempt to explain the mechanisms by which thunderstorm clouds become electrically charged and produce lightning.

Gravitational Theory
As shown in Stage I of Figure 1, in a mature thunder-storm cloud (a cloud beginning to precipitate), most precipitation particles, which may include raindrops, snow, or ice crystals, are initially neutral (no charge). As the larger particles (water droplets or ice crystals) in the upper regions of such a cloud fall due to gravity, they pass and rub against the smaller particles (see Stage II). The friction between them generates static electricity and places a negative charge on the larger particles as they settle to the cloud base. The smaller particles, which become positively charged through this process, rise to the top of the cloud (see Stage III). This separation of the positive and negative charges within the cloud is necessary for lightning formation.

Convective Theory
In this theory, the wind circulation within thunder-storm clouds is believed to cause the charge separation. Near the ground, some air molecules are positively charged. As updrafts (vertically rising currents of air) from the surface initiate the development of thunderstorm clouds, they also carry these positive charges aloft into the cloud (see Stage I of Figure 2). Initially, the entire cloud has a positive charge (Stage II). Negatively charged particles in the atmosphere are attracted toward the positively charged cloud and form a layer of negative charge around the edges of the cloud (Stage III). Strong downdrafts form as precipitation begins to fall and the thunderstorm reaches mature state (Stage IV). These downdrafts strip its the layer of negative charge from the cloud edge and carry it downward toward the base. The net effect of the convective circulation is to carry positively charged particles from the atmosphere to the cloud top and deposit negatively charged particles from the cloud's edge at the base of the cloud. This process continues through the remainder of the cloud's life cycle.
questions.question: 24. Which of the following represents an example of a cloud in which supporters of both theories would agree lightning would NOT occur?

choices.A: A cloud with large precipitation particles colliding with other smaller precipitation particles
choices.B: A cloud with updrafts and downdrafts moving charged particles from the atmosphere
choices.C: A cloud that only contains neutral particles
choices.D: A cloud with positive charges at the top of the cloud and negative charges at the base of the cloud

questions.title: V
questions.article:
Lightning is a visible electrical emission that often occurs in a cloud that has positive charges at the top and negative charges at the base (bottom). Two theories attempt to explain the mechanisms by which thunderstorm clouds become electrically charged and produce lightning.

Gravitational Theory
As shown in Stage I of Figure 1, in a mature thunder-storm cloud (a cloud beginning to precipitate), most precipitation particles, which may include raindrops, snow, or ice crystals, are initially neutral (no charge). As the larger particles (water droplets or ice crystals) in the upper regions of such a cloud fall due to gravity, they pass and rub against the smaller particles (see Stage II). The friction between them generates static electricity and places a negative charge on the larger particles as they settle to the cloud base. The smaller particles, which become positively charged through this process, rise to the top of the cloud (see Stage III). This separation of the positive and negative charges within the cloud is necessary for lightning formation.

Convective Theory
In this theory, the wind circulation within thunder-storm clouds is believed to cause the charge separation. Near the ground, some air molecules are positively charged. As updrafts (vertically rising currents of air) from the surface initiate the development of thunderstorm clouds, they also carry these positive charges aloft into the cloud (see Stage I of Figure 2). Initially, the entire cloud has a positive charge (Stage II). Negatively charged particles in the atmosphere are attracted toward the positively charged cloud and form a layer of negative charge around the edges of the cloud (Stage III). Strong downdrafts form as precipitation begins to fall and the thunderstorm reaches mature state (Stage IV). These downdrafts strip its the layer of negative charge from the cloud edge and carry it downward toward the base. The net effect of the convective circulation is to carry positively charged particles from the atmosphere to the cloud top and deposit negatively charged particles from the cloud's edge at the base of the cloud. This process continues through the remainder of the cloud's life cycle.
questions.question: 25. About which of the following points do the two theories differ?

choices.B: Initial location of charges in the cloud

questions.question: 26. According to the Gravitational Theory, the concentration of negative charge at the cloud base is greatest:

choices.A: when the raindrops inside the cloud are large.
choices.B: when the raindrops inside the cloud are small.
choices.C: when no rain is falling inside the cloud.

questions.question: 27. A research aircraft flies through the center of a mature thunderstorm cloud at a constant altitude and finds that most of the particles in that region are negatively charged. Both theories would agree that:

choices.A: no circulation is present to carry positively charged particles upward from the ground.
choices.B: most of the positively charged particles are suspended above this region.
choices.C: strong updrafts are occurring only at levels above this region.
choices.D: the entire cloud is negatively charged.

questions.question: 28. Florida experiences more thunderstorms than any other state. The Convective Theory would suggest that these storms most likely result from which of the following?

choices.A: A high negative charge in the air just above the ground
choices.B: A greater attractive force between positive and negative charges in this region
choices.C: A high frequency of updrafts over Florida
choices.D: A low frequency of updrafts over Florida

questions.question: 29. If a cloud consisted entirely of ice crystals, which of the following statements about this cloud would support the Gravitational Theory?

choices.A: Only the ice crystals with positive charge would fall and create a separation of charge.
choices.B: Positively charged ice crystals would attract negatively charged ice crystals from the atmosphere.
choices.C: The larger ice crystals would fall more rapidly than the smaller ice crystals and become negatively charged.
choices.D: Downdrafts cause the ice crystals to fall and therefore gain negative charge.

questions.question: 30. Lightning usually occurs when electrical current flows from regions of negative charge to regions with positive charge. Based on the Convective Theory, which lightning path is NOT possible?

choices.A: Within a cloud from base to top
choices.B: From the base of one cloud to the top of another
choices.D: Cloud base to a positively charged region of the atmosphere

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
An atom has a nucleus, which consists of protons (positively charged particles) and neutrons (uncharged particles), surrounded by one or more electrons (negatively charged particles) which move in orbits (see Figure 1).


Table 1 contains data for several neutral and charged atoms containing only one electron. Table 1 includes the number of protons (Z); the identification of the initial orbit (n); the radius of the orbit (r); the energy (l, in electron volts, or eV) to remove an electron from the atom; and the energy (E) of a photon emitted when an electron falls from its initial orbit to the orbit where n = 1.
questions.question: 31. For a given value of Z, the data indicate that as n increases, I:

choices.B: increases, then decreases.

choices.B: protons than neutrons.

questions.question: 34. The hypothesis that for a given value of n, r decreases as net positive charge increases, is supported by the data for:

choices.B: H and Li+2 only.

choices.B: n = 2 to n = 1 in Be+3.

questions.title: VII
questions.article:
Consider the following reaction:


At chemical equilibrium, the formation of hydrogen iodide gas (HI) occurs at the same rate as the formation of hydrogen (H2) and iodine (I2) gases.

At equilibrium, the equilibrium constant, (Keq), is the ratio of the square of the HI concentration ([HI]) to the product of the concentrations of H2 and I2. The table below shows the data collected while varying either the temperature or the initial reactant concentrations.
questions.question: 36. Which of the following pairs of trials in the table shows that reversing the initial concentrations of H2 and I2 at the same temperature gives the same final concentration of HI ?

choices.B: Trials 7 and 8

choices.B: decreases by one-fourth.

questions.question: 38. According to the table, increasing the reaction temperature, while keeping the total initial concentration of reactants constant, would result in which, if any, of the following concentration changes?

choices.A: A decrease in the initial concentration of H2 and I2
choices.B: A decrease in the final concentration of HI
choices.C: An increase in the initial concentration of H2 and I2
choices.D: No changes in the final concentration of the product

questions.question: 39. Based on the data in the table, which of the following statements best represents the relationship that exists between the Keq of a reaction and the temperature of that reaction?

choices.A: The Keq value decreases as the temperature is increased.
choices.B: The Keq value decreases then levels off as the temperature is increased.
choices.C: The Keq value stays the same as the temperature is increased.
choices.D: The Keq value increases as the temperature is increased.

questions.question: 40. Based on the information in the table, if the scientist had repeated the experiment at 400℃ and started with 2.0 mol L each of H2 and I2, the final concentration of HI would be closest to:

choices.B: 0.70 mol/L.
